summary: The document is an FBI communication from November 13, 1962, pertaining to the JFK assassination investigation. It focuses on John Roselli, detailing his activities, associations, and comments regarding investigations into his corporations. Roselli expressed confidence in avoiding detection due to internal arrangements. The document also mentions his association with Herman Spitzel, referred to as 'Commander', including Roselli's use of Spitzel's car and Spitzel's hospitalization. The document was reviewed and released with deletions, indicating some information was withheld.
key_findings: The document is part of the FBI's records on the JFK assassination, specifically focusing on John Roselli.
Roselli was observed at the Friar's Club in Beverly Hills and mentioned investigations into his corporations, expressing confidence they would find nothing due to internal obfuscation.
Herman Spitzel, a close friend and former employer of Roselli, is referred to as 'Commander' and was scheduled for hospitalization, with Roselli planning to use his car.
The document was reviewed and released with deletions, indicating some information was withheld from public disclosure.
